awd_titl_txt: Materials Research Science and Engineering Center
awd_abstract_narration:
****Nontechnical abstract****

The Harvard MRSEC focuses on highly collaborative multidisciplinary research with participants drawn from five departments across the university.  The overarching goal of the Center is to perform transformative research that significantly advances the state of knowledge in several areas of soft matter science, and to educate the next generation of leaders in materials science and engineering. The MRSEC has three interdisciplinary groups focused on very large deformations in soft materials, creating new materials for 3D printing and creating novel forms of soft machines. An essential contribution of the Center is to increase diversity of participants in its science at all levels, from undergraduate through graduate and postdoctoral to faculty. The Harvard MRSEC also sponsors a robust suite of activities to share the excitement of its science with the broader scientific community, and with the public at large. By combining soft matter science with cooking the Center elicits exhilaration through a public lecture series that combines science with talks by famous chefs; these are also posted online where there is an avid following, with the videos already attracting over 1.5M hits. The MRSEC is also developing special initiatives to bring returning veterans into STEM fields. By pooling resources for shared experimental facilities, the MRSEC supports a more extensive research effort. The resultant teamwork enables the Center to address problems that are larger in scale, and to produce results that are truly transformative. The MRSEC sets a standard of excellence for highly collaborative, multidisciplinary research. 

****Technical abstract****

The Harvard MRSEC supports highly collaborative, interdisciplinary research in several areas of soft matter science. These include investigations of the properties of soft materials subjected to very large deformations; development of fundamental knowledge essential to create and rapidly transform diverse classes of soft materials into 3D functional architectures; and development of the science of soft, non-linear unstable elastomeric materials and the use of these material instabilities to develop devices with high-value performance at lower cost. The Center also supports seed projects to enable rapid response to new developments; currently it supports an effort in developing tough fabrics to elicit interest among returning veterans, a group targeted by the MRSEC to help integrate into STEM careers. The MRSEC establishes a culture of innovation and entrepreneurship, enhancing the competitiveness of the national economy through industrial partnerships and formation of numerous start-up companies, creating more than 350 new high-tech jobs based directly on NSF support. Graduates of the Harvard MRSEC continue to be leaders in materials science and engineering, both nationally and internationally.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The vision of the Harvard Materials Research Science and Engineering Center (MRSEC) was to educate the next generation of scientists and engineers, while providing these students and postdoctoral researchers an environment that emphasizes scholarship and excellence, personal and scientific integrity, and a passion for exploration and knowledge.  The MRSEC focused on highly collaborative multidisciplinary research with participants drawn from five departments and two schools across the University. The Center performed transformative research that significantly advanced the state of knowledge of the design, mechanics, 3D printing, and dynamic behavior of soft materials.

The MRSEC had three interdisciplinary groups (IRG). IRG 1. Mechanics of soft materials established the mechanisms that determine the large-scale deformation of soft materials, created new, composite designer gels, developed a fundamental understanding of hydrofracture of soft materials, and explored the deformation and plastic flow of soft materials. IRG 2. Digital assembly of soft materials established the fundamental knowledge required to create and rapidly transform diverse classes of soft materials into 3D functional architectures to enable fabrication of new types of flexible, reconfigurable and heterogeneously integrated materials. IRG 3. Controlling and using instabilities in soft, elastic materials developed the science of soft, deformable, nonlinear, elastomeric materials, and used these materials in new soft devices that exploited their instabilities to give new types of performance.

The MRSEC also supported emerging areas through Seed and iSuperSeed Projects that responded rapidly to evolving ideas and helped move the Center in new directions. Seed funding was also used to bring new junior faculty members into the MRSEC and support innovations that promoted the Center?s mission of diversity or linked the MRSEC with industry, government or other sectors. iSuperSeed funding was used to support a multi-disciplinary investigation of soft materials for new cell-based therapies.

INTELLECTUAL MERIT

The intellectual merit of the Harvard MRSEC research and education was evident in the continuing tradition of high impact scholarship. From 2014-2022, the Center produced more than 495 publications, including 37 in Nature journals, 26 in Science journals, 34 in PRL, and 37 in PNAS that acknowledged this award.  As of December 2022, these papers have garnered more than 40,295 citations with an H-index of 95.  Of these publications, more than 25% were primarily supported by the Center and more than 50% of these primary publications had 2 or more MRSEC faculty members as authors.

BROADER IMPACTS

The most important impact of the Harvard MRSEC has been through the intellectual rigor and training the Center provided to the students and postdoctoral researchers; they have become the next generation of leaders among the scientists and engineers in both the country, and across the world. The MRSEC also sponsored a robust suite of activities to share the excitement of its science with the broader scientific community, and with the public at large. By combining soft matter science with cooking the Center elicits exhilaration through a public lecture series that combines science with talks by famous chefs; these Science and Cooking lectures are posted online where there is an avid following, with the videos already attracting over 5.5M hits.

The MRSEC recruited a diverse cadre of undergraduates and K12 teachers from across the county into to the Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) and Teachers (RET) summer programs. As cross-MRSEC collaborations, the Harvard MRSEC supported the quarterly New England Complex Fluids (NECF) Workshops established by the Harvard and Brandeis Centers with over 600 attendees annually as well as the highly popular Holiday Lecture reaching over 1000 children and parents in Cambridge and Princeton (Harvard and Princeton MRSECs) each December.

The MRSEC developed a new initiative that brought 30 returning veterans into STEM fields and established partnerships with minority serving schools at Florida A&M University, Southern University and Navajo Technical University.  These partnerships helped increase the number  of trainees supported by the Center with 25% of the graduate students and 33% of the postdoctoral researchers members of under-represented groups; the participation of women at the Center was also well above the national averages, with 40% of the graduate students and 50% of the postdoctoral researchers being women. These students and postdoctoral researchers are among the superb 31 graduate students and 26 postdoctoral researchers that completed their research programs during this award period. Finally, more than 29 startup companies have come from MRSEC-supported research, creating nearly 800 new high-quality jobs, directly impacting the nation?s economy.


Last Modified: 02/17/2023
Modified by: David A Weitz
